title: ENOENT using -r
body:
Trying to replace a non existing module with an existing one renders an ENOENT error.

``` bash
browserify -r constants:constants-browserify example/install-request.js
Error: ENOENT, open 'constants'
```

title: external deps are not parsed
body:
updates substack/node-browserify#401

I think this is the expected behavior for external dependencies.
We do no want their dependencies bundled, as they are with the external.

This patch adds external deps to _noParse, preventing their deps from
being included. It allows an option `parse` to be passed into `external()`,
in case someone is currently relying on the old behavior.

title: dependency stack creates a file path that can easily go past the 256 character limit
body:
I was working on a project on my windows machine (no chuckles, if you dev, you dev on windows, OSX, and _n_x =) and ran into a very interesting problem:

I'm working in C:\Users\Mike\Documents\Git Projects\processing-js, which is not an absurdly long dir name, and added browserify to allow me to build Processing.js for the browser based on how it gets built as node module. This works amazingly well, and then I figured I'd organise my git dir a bit better, putting processing-js in a "collaborations" dir. This lead to an error about the fact that there were files that went past 256 characters for their file path. As it turns out, browserify's dependency stack after an `npm install` has this in it:

`c:\users\mike\documents\Git projects\processing-js\node_modules\browserify\node_modules\browser-pack\node_modules\combine-source-map\node_modules\inline-source-map\node_modules\source-map\test\source-map\test-source-map-generator.js`

obviously this is not Browserify's fault, it's kind of a compound problem if you're running self-contained modules, with everything having a `node_modules` dir, but it's still wortk pointing out; the Browserify dependency tree runs deep, and if `source-map` ever decides it needs another dependency, things might become impossible to work with (at least on Windows) even on shallow project directories.

I'm not sure what would be good ways to solve this problem at the Browserify level, but I figured it would be good to point out that this problem exists, because the last thing you want is to end up having to say "this package is not supported on windows" because of some deep dependency path lengths, rather than actual code problems.

title: Changed ignore to external in multiple bundles build script
body: The multiple bundles example was not working. Fixed as proposed in #291

title: Advanced Cache
body:
I really want a way to speed up building browserify modules.  It occurs to me that most of the time is spent doing the parsing of dependencies.  These rarely change so could be easily cached.  My proposal is to add an option that writes a `"browserify-cache"` field to `package.json` which contains a map from file path (relative to package.json) to an object containing:

``` js
{
  deps: ['./dep.js', 'jquery'],
  globals: {implicit: ['Buffer', 'window'], exported: ['exports']}
  hash: 'MD5-hash of the source code when this was last updated'
}
```

This way, the time taken to parse most modules would be reduced to the time taken to verify the MD5 hash.

This cache could be easily generated using a separate `browserify build-cache` command, and could even be pre-populated on publish by some conscientious package authors.

The advantage would be that this would largely remove the need to add `opts.noParse = ['jquery']` etc. since those would only ever get parsed once.

title: Browserify doesn't read package.json if entry file is nested in a subdirectory
body: Discovered this because my testling tests are nested in a subdirectory, and browserify didn't pick up my transforms in the `package.json`.

title: Symlinked packages duplicated in browserify (but not in node)
--ignore doesn't make the bundle fall back to previous require for loading dependencies
body:
Thanks for browserify, it's the swiss army knife I was looking for.

I have one question regarding --ignore, I can hardly find any documentation and the line in the documentation doesn't clearly explain its intent.

What I guess it does is:
Given a module B that depends on A, when --ignore is used then B doesn't include A.

As a result, I would imagine B falling back to a previous require to try and load A.

If that's not the case, then what is --ignore used for? Can we add a new options to handle the use case I've described?

Otherwise, it doesn't work, as B gets an empty object for A, although A can still be required from the global scope. I'm happy to make a pull request as I have a fix.

I've posted something on stack overflow which I will keep up to date with the answer that I'll get from here: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/17383665/browserify-to-load-dependencies-from-global-scopes-require-instead-of-expecting

I'm using browserify 2.22

Cheers,
Olivier

title: Auto inclusion of Buffer includes object, not function
body:
When using the auth param on the http module it uses a buffer function for calculating the base64 encoding. It seems to try using the Buffer object as a function.

(minimal testcase)

var http = require('http');
var req = http.request({hostname:'www.google.com', auth: 'hello:world'}, function(res) {});

browserified version will throw object as function exception.

Tested with:
browserify 2.22.0
node v0.10.11
Chrome 27

title: entry module for --standalone provided in browser-pack
body: Depends on substack/browser-pack#15, and hopefully fixes substack/node-browserify#430.

title: sourceMappingURL has been changed to "//#"
body:
Chrome gives warning:

```
"//@ sourceMappingURL=" source mapping URL declaration is deprecated,
"//# sourceMappingURL=" declaration should be used instead. 
```

More infomation here:
http://updates.html5rocks.com/2013/06/sourceMappingURL-and-sourceURL-syntax-changed
Some issues found on Github:
https://github.com/search?q=sourceMappingURL&ref=cmdform&type=Issues

title: Support `FormData` in `http`
body:
Posting FormData can be done using something like:

``` js
  var fd = new FormData()
  fd.append('image', file)
  var req = new XMLHttpRequest()
  req.onload = function () {
    callback(null, req.responseText)
  }
  req.onerror = callback
  req.open('post', 'https://api.imgur.com:443/3/image.json')
  req.setRequestHeader('Authorization', 'Client-ID ' + clientID)
  req.send(fd)
```

However, I can see know way of handling `FormData` using the built in `http` module.

title: Error: EMFILE on OSX when requiring lots of files
body:
When requiring 256 files from a single file on OSX browserify throws:

```
Error: EMFILE, open '/Users/karl/Sites/KVP/GuruFramework/package.json'
```

From Googling around it looks like this is caused by attempting to open too many files in parallel.

It looks like this could be solved by using the `graceful-fs` module to limit the number of files opened in parallel.

https://github.com/isaacs/node-graceful-fs

title: Find module from root of classpath
body:
I am working on using browserify to convert some applications built with Brunch.io over to be built with Grunt.

The only thing that is hanging me up is that with Brunch (which got this from skitch) if you dont specify a relative directory it pulls it from the root of the project, or the classpath of sorts.  Because of the nature of browserify this behaviour is looking for a node module.

Building apps with backbone I may need to create a new instance of a Model from a view, which means I have to hard code the path from the view to the model which can be a bit of a mess.

I am not suggesting we change the behaviour of how browserify looks up modules but I am wondering if you have any suggestions on a notation I might add that would allow it to look for the path of the included relative to the initial included file.  Perhaps a / prepeneded or a ~.

I believe I have found a good place to put this, but I was curious if any one else already had done this or would find it useful.

title: Update to browser-resolve 1.1.0
body:
Update to browser-resolve 1.1.0 now that the necessary patches for #420 have been merged and published.

The  test change reverts back to the original test that was changed here:
https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/commit/fac795d82cf5bcb1ae0d282480e11437fe080cf9#L2L31

The difference was cause by `packageFilter` within browser-resolve 1.0.1 being too generous in its legacy check (https://github.com/shtylman/node-browser-resolve/blob/v1.0.1/index.js#L145)

Now (https://github.com/shtylman/node-browser-resolve/blob/master/index.js#L154) it uses the same check as browserify itself (https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/blob/master/index.js#L332)

title: Add decomponentify and debowerify to list of source transforms in README
body:
With decomponentify you can you can freely intermix browerify and TJ's [component](https://github.com/component/component) modules for inclusion into the compiled bundle.

With debowerify you can more easily mix and require [bower](http://bower.io) packages and use them with browserify.

title: --debug source maps are using a deprecated pragma
body:
Hi @substack,

It looks like all the major browser manufacturers are following the Mozilla recommendation to change the pragma for Source Map urls from an @ symbol to an # symbol, as per this issue for Firefox:

https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=870361

All relevant browsers now support the # format, and Chrome is now generating an annoying deprecation warning every time I run browserify in debug mode.

Happy to generate a pull request if you like, it should be a trivial change.

title: Support package metadata in resolution process.
body:
This patch builds on the support of the following patches to browserify's dependencies:

https://github.com/substack/node-resolve/pull/21
https://github.com/shtylman/node-browser-resolve/pull/23
https://github.com/substack/module-deps/issues/13

With all this in place, transforms are correctly applied to any package dependencies.

Whew! I think that's it. I'd love to get all this merged and published to npm.  Please let me know if there's any questions or changes that need to be made.

Cheers!

body: With this transform you can freely intermix Node and AMD modules for inclusion into the compiled bundle.

title: Update usage.txt
body: Needs to be --help instead of help

title: Allow passing opts to constructor, and add.
body:
Currently there doesn't seem to be a nice way to tell browserify the correct base directory; There is no way to pass opts at all. 

For my use case, I use browserify programmatically to dynamically generate javascript packages for the client side my application; a large multiplayer game engine. The problem is that proccess.cwd() points to my parent module, but browserify is use in a sub module that has a different root. This allows one to pass my own basedir, as well as any other options I may wish to pass to browserify's require().

strange module names on bundle(), non working code
body:
Hi! I'm trying to create [browserify version of angular](https://github.com/darvin/angular.js) . 
I'm doing this:

```
  shim(browserify(), {
    "angular": { path: './build/angular.js', exports: 'angular' },
    "angular-cookies": { path: './build/angular-cookies.js', exports: 'angular-cookies', depends: {"angular":"angular"} },
    "angular-resource": { path: './build/angular-resource.js', exports: 'angular-resource', depends: {"angular":"angular"} },
  })
  .bundle({},function (err, src) {
    if (err) return console.error(err);
    fs.writeFileSync(OUTPUT, src);
  });
```

The output file is looking strange, there is garbage looking module exports , called `reBOaC`, `BgUQU8` and etc.

title: How to specify files to bundle for later (semi-)dynamic require
body: I need to require some files based on a data attribute on some elements to be able to revive views that were rendered server-side and should continue to work client-side or in order to be able to use some declarative way of specifying the templates a view should use eg ```

title: nested "browser" field breaks
body:
Say you have this dependency tree where `A` and `B` depend on `C` and `A` depends on `C`.

```
A
|---C
|---B
    |---C
```

When `A` and `B` depend on the same version of `C`, npm will not install `C` into `B`'s `node_modules` folder. Still, everything works as intendet.

Now, `C` is not `npm` compatible, so `A` and `B` state in their `package.json`:

``` js
"browser": {
  "C": "node_modules/c-component/index.js"
}
```

This breaks for `B` as it can't find the file there, only `A` has it.

Either `node_modules/c-component/index.js` should be looked up at all parents of `B` dependency (in this case `A`) if it can't be found or there needs to be a way to specify:

``` js
"browser": {
  "C": "c-component"
}
```

which would be a simple rename.

cc @shtylman

title: make --ignore-missing actually ignore missing requires
body: Right now, it appears --ignore-missing does nothing. This change causes it to actually ignore missing require targets, with a warning.

title: brfs and coffeeify not usable together
body:
I am not sure where this fails or whether this is already documented but i tried to use brfs and  coffeeify together and brfs did not work on coffee files. 

The files were translated to js but brfs did not work . I assume its not actually a pipeline and brfs works on the coffee file which does not work obviously. swapping the parameters did not make a difference.

```
browserify -t brfs -t coffeeify test.coffee

browserify -t coffeeify -t brfs test.coffee
```

in both cases the output still contained the fs.readFileSync call.

using coffee compiler first and then calling browserify on the js file worked as expected.

title: Errors in package.json give not meaningful output.
body:
So it took me several hours to figure out what was going wrong when attempting to pass file through a browserify. In the end I discovered that package.json in one of the packages had syntax error that somehow affected browserify even though that package.json was not actually used. The problem was with browser-resolver https://github.com/shtylman/node-browser-resolve/blob/master/index.js#L56 erroring with no useful message, now that it has a more meaningful error browserify could probably update to improve this.

I think I'd like to generalize this issue and request a better error reporting, for example if module can't be resolved then include in message which module failed to require and requiring what. If JS/JSON file has an error mentioning file would be great even better if it included line number etc..

I am new to browserify so don't be polite if this is a stupid question.

title: Provide scope for require() or require.noConflict()
Create parent folder for output file if it doesn't exist
body: Just to make life easier it would be nice if browserify could create the parent folder of the output file.

title: Browserify includes required from modules defined as external
body:
_(Transitive dependency in this context means module A requires module B, and module B requires module C. Hence, module C is a transitive dependency of A)._

When module A has a transitive dependency only module C through module B which is external (not included), browserify still includes that dependency (C).

I think it should be expected from the external bundle to include those dependencies, instead of having to manually externalize each of them.

I have included an extension of the docs example (beep, boop, robot) for what I mean at https://gist.github.com/amitayd/5580837 .

Currently, `browserify beep.js -x robot.js` would include beep.js **and circuit.js** (which is only used by robot.js).

I believe the expected behaviour including only beep.js.

_Implementation notes_

I only had a brief look at the code base so i might be entirely wrong, but it seems that the list of files and their dependency is gathered from module-deps for all required files, and the returned list does not include the origins/requiree(s) of the dependency, so it's a problem to filter them in browserify.

One solution is to pass the externals filter to be used by module-deps when walking the dependencies.

Another is the module-deps can return something like origin modules array for each row, then browserify can work like this:
If _all_ of row dependencies are external, skip.

title: Cannot set property 'parent' of null
body:
Hello!

Im currently using browserify in a project, and it works really great so far. Unfortunatelly, I got a pullrequest which breaks browserify for unknown reasons:

```
Error: Parsing file /Users/tox/src/terminal.js/lib/term_writer.js: Cannot set property 'parent' of null
```

After some patching in browserify, I was able to output a stacktrace:

```
TypeError: Cannot set property 'parent' of null
    at /Users/tox/src/terminal.js/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/module-deps/node_modules/detective/index.js:7:22
    at Array.forEach (native)
    at traverse (/Users/tox/src/terminal.js/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/module-deps/node_modules/detective/index.js:6:14)
    at /Users/tox/src/terminal.js/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/module-deps/node_modules/detective/index.js:17:13
    at Array.forEach (native)
    at traverse (/Users/tox/src/terminal.js/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/module-deps/node_modules/detective/index.js:14:27)
    at /Users/tox/src/terminal.js/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/module-deps/node_modules/detective/index.js:17:13
    at Array.forEach (native)
    at traverse (/Users/tox/src/terminal.js/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/module-deps/node_modules/detective/index.js:14:27)
    at /Users/tox/src/terminal.js/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/module-deps/node_modules/detective/index.js:8:13
```

To reproduce this issue, you can do the following:

```
# git clone git://github.com/jedi4ever/terminal.js.git
# cd terminal.js
# git checkout 8892974
# npm install
# ./node_modules/browserify/bin/cmd.js -s terminal index.js -o dist/terminal.js -r ./extern/_stream_writable.js:_stream_writable -r ./extern/stream.js:stream -r ./extern/dummy.js:_stream_passthrough -r ./extern/dummy.js:_stream_readable -r ./extern/dummy.js:_stream_transform -r ./extern/dummy.js:_stream_duplex
```

title: Check raw require() ids against ignore list
body:
ignore now works with relative paths and module names.

Fixes #398

title: Allow ignores by relative path
body:
Right now, the `ignore` option is checked on resolved filenames.  (https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/blob/master/index.js#L320)

This means that specifying a package name in `ignore` has no effect.

`_resolve` should also check `id` against the ignore list.

title: Support filenames in browser-pack
body:
Defaults to true

Requires SLaks/browser-pack@de48689

Without this PR, browser-pack will only be able to see filenames if source maps are enabled.

title: Add link to rfolderify
body: Me again. Here's another source transformer. This one turns calls to `rfolder` into a map of filenames to `require` calls for all the things in the folder.

title: coffee-script source maps support
body:
It is good to add an `browserify` option to support external source map during the compilation like uglify-js did.

```
coffee -o script.js -cm script.coffee
uglifyjs script.js -o script.min.js --source-map script.min.js.map --in-source-map script.js.map
```

This way errors in browser will show the correct line inside coffee but not js file.

title: How can I add modules dynamically once the bundle has been compiled?
Automatic global insertion for Buffer results double code
body:
When global insertion kicks in for Buffer, two versions of `buffer-browserify` are added to the bundle. One is from `insert-module-globals` and other from `node-browser-resolve`.

This is not only the file size issue. Because there are two different definitions it breaks `Buffer.isBuffer` and `instanceof Buffer`.

Made a tshirt out of browserify.

http://teespring.com/browserify

No spam intended. We love you substack and browserify. :)

Using the `standalone` and `debug` flags together causes problems
body:

Will dig into the problem deeper soon, and if something jumps out will submit a pull request...

title: Updated checkSyntax err output to include ref to problem file, line number and column
body: Please see: https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/issues/388

title: Compile-time syntax errors in source do not produce useful stack traces
body:
During development I'm finding it difficult to track down errors if there are problems parsing the source.  

Given this bit of erroneous code in `View.js`:

```
var View = function () {} z; 

module.exports = View;
```

The stack trace returned is 

```
Fatal error: Unexpected identifier

    at Object.<anonymous> (/path/to/project/build/node_modules/grunt-browserify2/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/syntax-error/index.js:46:24)
    at Module._compile (module.js:456:26)
    at Object.Module._extensions..js (module.js:474:10)
    at Module.load (module.js:356:32)
    at Function.Module._load (module.js:312:12)
    at Module.require (module.js:364:17)
    at require (module.js:380:17)
    at Object.<anonymous> (/path/to/project/build/node_modules/grunt-browserify2/node_modules/browserify/index.js:5:19)
    at Module._compile (module.js:456:26)
    at Object.Module._extensions..js (module.js:474:10)
```

Which fails to show where the error was found.  It would be nice to have a line number and file location, if possible, or the ablity to turn off compile-time checks in favor of letting the browser handle it.

title: external('file') breaks if browserify can't resolve 'file'.
body:
So, I want to provide my own versions of the core modules,
not to run them in the browser, but instead to run them in a secure context.

From what I can see, I should use `browserify.external(file)` to tell browserify that i'm using an external module, however, this breaks if the module required is not provided by browserify-resolve.

example:

``` js
var browserify = require('browserify')
var path = require('path')

var secure = browserify(path.resolve(process.argv[2]))

var core = [
  "assert"   , "buffer_ieee754", "buffer"        , "child_process"
, "cluster"  , "console"       , "constants"     , "crypto"
, "_debugger", "dgram"         , "dns"           , "domain"
, "events"   , "freelist"      , "fs"            , "http"  
, "https"    , "_linklist"     , "module"        , "net" 
, "path"     , "punycode"      , "querystring"   , "readline"
, "repl"     , "stream"        , "string_decoder", "sys"
, "timers"   , "tls"           , "tty"           , "url"
, "util"     , "vm"            , "zlib"          , "os"
]

//don't bundle any core modules
core.forEach(function (m) {
  secure.external(m)
})


secure
  .bundle()
  .pipe(process.stdout)
```

I get this error:

``` js
events.js:71
        throw arguments[1]; // Unhandled 'error' event
                       ^
Error: module "buffer_ieee754" not found in require()
    at Browserify.require (/Users/dominictarr/c/node_modules/browserify/index.js:58:46)
    at resolve (/Users/dominictarr/c/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/browser-resolve/index.js:115:16)
    at Browserify.require (/Users/dominictarr/c/node_modules/browserify/index.js:56:5)
    at Browserify.external (/Users/dominictarr/c/node_modules/browserify/index.js:95:17)
    at /Users/dominictarr/c/securify/index.js:21:10
    at Array.forEach (native)
    at Object.<anonymous> (/Users/dominictarr/c/securify/index.js:20:6)
    at Module._compile (module.js:449:26)
    at Object.Module._extensions..js (module.js:467:10)
    at Module.load (module.js:356:32)
```

the error comes from here:

https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/blob/master/index.js#L59

which is before the bit that checks whether that file should be excluded.

https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/blob/master/index.js#L71-L73

So, it has to be able to resolve modules that I want to exclude... which seems unnecessary,
especially for non-relative modules.

title: Globals
Chrome apps don't allow unload event handlers
body:
I'm trying to use browserify (2.11.0) to build a chrome packaged app but I get this error:
`Uncaught beforeunload is not available in packaged apps.`

I also get the same for the unload event as well. Turns out chrome packaged apps are not supposed to use these.

According to chrome app dev docs, the onSuspend seems to be the equivalent that chrome packaged apps are supposed to use:
http://developer.chrome.com/trunk/apps/app_lifecycle.html#clean-up

I'm currenty looking for the spot in browserify where this is occurring and hope to be able to put together a pull request.

title: Documentation really sketchy on how to export a module
body:
I've been going back and forth the `README` and code for a while now trying to understand how the damn this is supposed to be used for exposing a module in the browser.

The beep-poop example and `README` mention of a `--require` flag but that even fails in the example's `build.sh` as `robot.js` is not a module in `./node_modules`, but just a file.

Then an attempt to use `--require` with a relative path ends up meaning you'll have to use `require("./foo")` in the browser as well, as opposed to just using `require("foo")`. Oh, hey, `Optionally use a colon separator to set the target.`, but that's not even implemented according to #319?!

Symlink the name of your library to your `index.js` and relative `--require` that? Well, that prints out peculiar useless intermediary requires named in the style of `"l5QO1E"`.

So, how do you package an existing `index.js` file so you can do `require("foo")` in the browser?

How about adding a header which is similar to CoffeeScript's?

``` js
// Generated by CoffeeScript 1.6.2
```

title: Browserify a Browserified module
body:
So I have three modules to use in an app in a browser.

`module-b` depends on `module-a`.

`module-a` depends on `Handlebars` and is composed of several individual internal dependencies, relatively required as in the documentation. `module-a`'s foo.js requires bar.js, like so:

```
var Handlebars = require('handlebars');
var bar = require('./bar.js');
```

I browserify `module-a`. I run it through tests, and everything is good and index.js is produced and it contains foo, bar, and Handlebars and the exports look good and are tested via the requires in the test, so, I `npm link module-a`.

I go to `module-b` and `npm link module-a`, which installs a symlink in the node_modules folder of `module-b`.

When I browserify `module-b`, which has a statement of `var module-a = require('module-a');`, I get a bunch of browserify errors, like the following:

```
Error: module "./handlebars/base" not found from "/home/blah/Development/module-b/node_modules/module-a/index.js"
```

This seems strange, since `module-a` is already browserified.  I've tried with `-r module-a`, `-x module-a`, `--ignore-missing`, `-i 'handlebars'`. Browserify just keeps spitting out the same error. I assume that it would fail for `module-a's` internal `./bar.js` dependency as well, but it dies before it even gets that far.

Is this expected behavior, is it a bug, or am I not configuring the cli call to browserify correctly?

title: unable to specify transform modules in windows

> browserify -t browserify-ejs index.js

> 7:22)

> e_modules\resolve\lib\async.js:106:35)

> _modules\resolve\lib\async.js:18:18)
>     at Object.oncomplete (fs.js:297:15)

it's possible to do this as a workaround:

> browserify -t ./node_modules/browserify-ejs index.js

which, because it starts with a dot, causes a path.resolve in browserify's index.js

title: browserify wrapper needs to set this context to window
provide a --list command
body:
I'd like to write a concise Makefile rule with the correct dependencies:

```
bundle.js: $(shell browserify --list main.js)
  browserify main.js > bundle.js
```

This is inspired by @mbostock's [smash](https://github.com/mbostock/smash).

title: --deps flag does not work
body:
`Browserify.prototype.deps` doesn't check `self._pending` like `Browserify.prototype.bundle` does, so `browserify --deps index.js` always outputs empty JSON.

This option isn't documented, maybe the functionality should just be removed?

title: -s is giving strange, invalid JS
body:
So, I very well could be misunderstanding how to use this but I'm doing:

```
$ browserify -s index.js > browser.js
```

for https://raw.github.com/OscarGodson/ctor/master/index.js

This results in:

``` js
(function(e){if("function"==typeof bootstrap)bootstrap("index.js",e);else if("object"==typeof exports)module.exports=e();else if("function"==typeof define&&define.amd)define(e);else if("undefined"!=typeof ses){if(!ses.ok())return;ses.makeIndexjs=e}else"undefined"!=typeof window?window.indexjs=e():global.indexjs=e()})(function(){var define,ses,bootstrap,module,exports;
return (function(e,t,n){function i(n,s){if(!t[n]){if(!e[n]){var o=typeof require=="function"&&require;if(!s&&o)return o(n,!0);if(r)return r(n,!0);throw new Error("Cannot find module '"+n+"'")}var u=t[n]={exports:{}};e[n][0](function(t){var r=e[n][1][t];return i(r?r:t)},u,u.exports)}return t[n].exports}var r=typeof require=="function"&&require;for(var s=0;s<n.length;s++)i(n[s]);return i})({},{},[])(undefined)
});
;
```

There's quite a few things wrong here:
1. two semicolons back to back?
2. I get `Error: Cannot find module 'undefined'` when trying to use this code
3. `Ctor` is never exported to window
4. It's missing all the required modules

This seems super wrong and I must be blind. So, how would I:

Create a minified, concatenated, `browser.js` file? How do I create an _unminified_ version of this file too?

Fix browsers typo

title: Add programmatic usage example to readme
body: I can't currently find any docs on requiring browserify and using it from your own program.

title: Generate external bundle automatically from --external for async loading
body:
Lets enable awesome asynchronous bundle loading with Browserify!: :)

When we have [reverse/lazy bundles](https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/pull/360) working we can start thinking how we could use them more efficiently.

I'd like to change or add new kind of --external switch that works like this:
1. Takes two arguments input and output. Example: `--external ./graph.js:graph-bundle.js`
2. Recusively resolves all the dependencies that are used in the `graph.js` module in to a tree
3. From that tree it removes those dependencies that are used in the main bundle
4. Writes main bundle to stdout without `graph.js` and its dependencies
5. Writes second bundle to `graph-bundle.js` with `graph.js` and its dependencies that are not already in the main bundle
# Example

We have app.js with following require calls:

```
app.js
├─jquery.js
└─┬─graph.js
  ├─jquery.js
  └─flotr.js
```

To build `app-bundle.js` and `graph-bundle.js` we do

```
browserify --extract ./graph.js:graph-bundle.js app.js > app-bundle.js
```

and it builds `app-bundle.js` with code from following dependencies:

```
app.js
└─jquery.js
```

and `graph-bundle.js` with our graph drawing code and flotr library for doing the canvas stuff:

```
graph.js
 └─flotr.js
```

Note how `jquery.js` code is not present here although it is used in `graph.js` because it can access the one in `app-bundle.js` using the [require chains](https://github.com/substack/browser-pack/pull/10).

Now the app.js can lazy load the graph code only when needed by doing something like:

``` javascript
var $ = require("./jquery");

$("button.show-graph").on("click", function(){
    // Users rarely use the graph view so load the graph
    // code only when the view is requested
    $.getScript("graph-bundle.js", function(){
        var drawGraph = require("./graph");
        $(".graph-container").html(drawGraph());
    });
});
```

Do you feel this is doable? Currently this is possible to do with whole bunch of --external and --require calls, but it's way too much work and error prone to be actually usable.

Also the api/cli cli interface could be something complete different than presented here.

title: Add failing test: reverse multi bundle
body:
On the way to enable lazy asynchronous bundle loading :)

Fixed in browser-pack pull request https://github.com/substack/browser-pack/pull/10

title: How do I specify browser versions of core modules?
body:
I have a node module that uses the node core module `os`. The only thing from `os` that my module uses is `os.EOL`. I've read the documentation but can't figure out how to tell browserify to use an alternate version of `os`, so I get errors when browserify comes across `require('os')` saying:

```
Error: module not found: "os" from file C:\Users\kastor\Desktop\atropa-ide\node_modules\atropa-jsformatter\src\atropa-jsformatter.js
```

I'm thinking that it's possible by using the `browser` field in the `package.json` of my module but I haven't figured out how to make it work properly.

My browser version of `os` looks like

```
module.exports.EOL = '\n';
```

If I could get browserify to find my `os` then I'd be able to browserify [atropa-jsformatter](https://github.com/matthewkastor/atropa-jsformatter/blob/gh-pages/src/atropa-jsformatter.js). The reason it's important to me is that when I format javascript through node I want the OS specific line endings used in the output file. On the browser, I'm trying to integrate my formatter with the ace code editor. The ace code editor has a setting for choosing line endings so I can just read that setting and overwrite the value stored in `os.EOL` and everything would work out great.

title: Predictable module order
body: The bundle hash is different each time I run browserify, because the modules are written to the file in different order each time. I would like to use the hash of the source to fingerprint and cache the file on clients. But because the hash changes each time that's not going to work. Would it be possible to make the order predictable (eg. sort the modules by name)?

title: Change script filename in example
body: I assume this should be `main` rather than `entry`. Wasn't exactly clear to me where `entry.js` suddenly came from.

title: Report errors when bundling more than one file for standalone
body:
Standalone relies on the assumption that there's only one entry file.

If there are multiple, it will just treat the first one as the `exported` module.  This probably isn't the best behavior.

This would make using https://github.com/thlorenz/es6ify along with standalone pretty much impossible I think, since the runtime has to come before the module.  One option would be to switch to considering the last (entry) module to be bundled as being the export of the package.

Alternatively just error and say that "browserify standalone doesn't support multiple entry files"

title: Standalone
body: Adds a standalone option as per #327
